awd_titl_txt: UNOLS: Management of Marine Technical Support
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF Solicitation 15-525 requested proposals from institutions for the Management of the UNOLS Technician Pool. 

The Technical Services Program in Ocean Sciences (OCE) at NSF provides funding for support activities both at sea and shore-side for a variety of oceanographic research projects. This support is generally provided by the staff of full time technicians at the operating institutions in the Academic Fleet. During periods when the support demands are greater than the available personnel, the institution hires or borrows (from another operating institution) additional technicians on an ad hoc basis. Conversely, when an institution has a weak schedule, the size of the technical support staff does not adjust and technicians may be underutilized. The NSF, in conjunction with the Technical Support Manager at the UNOLS office, has instituted a process whereby the exchange of full-time technicians between Ship Operating Institutions can occur without the burden of sending invoices and payment between institutions. 

The next step in this process is the establishment of a fleet-wide Technician Pool where a portion of the sea-going workforce is comprised of non-institution-specific, contract personnel that are utilized as needed. The goals of the Tech Pool are two-fold:
?	To provide the Technical Support Managers in the fleet more flexibility in achieving the optimal staffing levels, both ashore and at sea.
?	To more efficiently manage the personnel resources in the fleet in the face of level or shrinking budgets.
NSF is aware that many institutions have HR policies that make it difficult to hire temporary/part time employees. The hiring of non-full-time, contract technicians through a single UNOLS institution would address this issue and provide a resource for operators in the fleet. 

A 4-member panel convened on July 30, 2015 to discuss 4 proposals submitted to the Oceanographic Technical Services Program in response to Solicitation NSF 15-525. The solicitation involved the management of the UNOLS Marine Technician Pool.

The Program recommends that the award for the hosting of the UNOLS Technician Pool be given to Texas A&M University. The award should be a five-year cooperative agreement. The initial budget, as well as the out year budgets, will be negotiated at a later time when a better idea of the ship schedules are known.

The following proposals will therefore be declined:
1543749	University of Miami
1543442	Scripps Institution of Oceanography
1542791	University of Washington.

1543166	Texas A&M University will be recommended.

por.por_cntn:
Despite the best efforts of the oceanographic scientific community to take advantage of automated and autonomous systems, it is still necessary to send people to sea on a regular basis, to deploy and service moorings and other instrumentation, such as AUVs and ROVs, and to conduct surveys. Such ship operations are expensive, and the number of ships in the U.S. research fleet has been decreasing since about 2007. 

 

The loss of ships meant that several highly-skilled marine technicians, who operate the complex instrumentation required to carry out marine research, and who were employed full-time by ship operators, became “homeless.” NSF did not want to lose their experience, and established a pool whose members could be used on any research ship as needed. Texas A&M University was awarded a 5-year Cooperative Agreement (since renewed) to run the pool. The pool does not include all marine technicians, (UNOLS ship operators all have their own permanent staff), but it allows PIs to engage specialized operators when needed, or when additional technical personnel are required for shipboard operations.

 

Members of the pool are classed as self-employed individual contractors, with salaries based on their qualifications and experience. They are hired as needed and paid at standard day rates plus expenses incurred getting to and from vessels. They are responsible for their own medical insurance coverage, but Liability and Workmen’s Compensation Insurance are covered through a group policy. This allows us the flexibility required to cope with short-term requests for pool support, changes in staffing requirements or changes in ship scheduling. The scheduling of pool members is made by the UNOLS Technical Service Manager, in conjunction with the chief scientists of the relevant cruises. Pool members who spend more than 100 days a year on deployment are allowed to attend conferences or training sessions at pool expense.

 

The pool started with 2 members in 2016 and has grown during the project’s lifetime so that there were 18 members in mid-2022. An additional 14 individuals have been pool members during the period of the Cooperative Agreement; some did not have their contracts renewed, others either were hired permanently by ship operators or took other positions. There is no guarantee of employment for pool members, and some pool members spend considerably more time on contract than others. Deployments can vary from 2-3 days to 90 days depending on requirements. The overall number of deployments in each year varied between a low of 17 (2016) to 50 (2018 and 2019), but the Covid epidemic during 2020 and 2021 meant that ship operations in general and deployments, specifically, were very considerably curtailed. The total number of deployments during the 2016-2022 period was 210, and pool members spent a total on 5208 days deployed. As expected from the variation in annual deployments, days worked each year also varied, from a low of 349 in 2016 to highs of 1341 in 2017 and 1280 in 2018.

 

The value of the pool has been established based on comments received from cruise PIs and ship operators. Such comments (anonymized) include:

 

  1. “X was exceptional as the lead technician. He was helpful during the planning, ensuring we requested the correct winches, etc. During the cruise, he went out of his way to ensure that the various objectives of the science party were met safely and efficiently. X’s skills, dedication, and hard work were a significant reason for the success of the cruise, and the entire science party was impressed by his skill and appreciative of his efforts.”

 

  1. "The marine techs provided excellent support for our science mission, setting up and configuring the CTD/rosette and Mocness, and assisting with each deployment. A in particular took an active role in our scientific operations, and both A and B worked long hours with good cheer and made absolutely critical contributions to our scientific effort. We experienced no significant problems with shipboard equipment or instrumentation. (winches, CTD/rosette, MOCNESS).” 

 

  1. “D from the UNOLS Tech Pool ran the deck for our cruise because our staff deck lead was not available. D was great. He's knowledgeable, skilled, energetic, safe, calm, and professional. He exudes a positive can-do attitude. We look forward to sailing with him again in the future.”

 

Advantages of the pool include keeping hard-won knowledge within the marine technician community, allowing younger technicians to meet and work with more experienced members and keep up with new, cutting-edge instrumentation, and, for ship operators, to see how pool members operate in case of a need for permanent hiring (nine former pool members were hired permanently in this way). The flexibility offered allows pool members to work when they want to or follow other opportunities, and, based on comments received, they seem to enjoy the chance to see how things operate on different vessels and to meet new people.

Modified by: Piers Chapman
